ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I developed a deep understanding of the complex intellectual history of archaeology.
Understanding of movements in archaeology. Better grasp of archaeological theory and the history of the development of this discipline.

This was a very insightful class with regards to archaeological theory. Seeing Prof. McIntosh's approach to the class - starting it in the Enlightenment - expanded my understanding of the antiquity of these debates, and was quite helpful. Class time was also well-spent for the lectures and discussions we had about the readings for the week and the importance of them in the larger scheme of the history of archaeological theory.
Great insights into the theoretical paradigms of archaeology.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Great readings, fascinating class discussions, and an intellectually stimulating experience.
Enjoy discussions. Lecture + discussion of each person's weekly reading assignment was helpful. Enjoyed group work. No complaints.
Professor could organize the class in a way in which each and every student can be involved in every session and gain knowledge.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course highly.
Yes. Necessary for any archaeology student.

Yes, I would recommend this to another student, and will do so if it is offered again during my time here. It functions both as a good class for understanding archaeological theory and also as a "cohort-bonding-exercise", as people in the department commonly take it at the same point in their graduate careers.
Absolutely! Every student in archaeology should take this course.
